comments.body: This doesn't look right, `MaskedArray` isn't a dtype.

        y = x.view(np.ndarray)
        y = x.view(type=np.ndarray)

comments.body: I don't think this array is big enough, see above.

The rewrite is correct, I think.  The original,

```
fill_value = np.array((-999, -12345678.9, "???"), dtype=object) 
```

indeed produces an array with three objects, but that does not pass the test. By first creating an array to hold objects, I can fill the first entry with a single tuple holding all three values. I did not know how to invoke `nd.array` such that it treats the tuple as a single object....

Hmm, I noticed this fails on Travis for python 3.2 and 3.3 (but is OK for 2.7) -- since this test never ran properly anyway, shall I comment it out for now? It might be best not to start debugging too much here.
The original test failed? Was it run?

The original test (1384-1385 of original) did

```
fill_value = np.array((-999, -12345678.9, "???"), dtype=object)
fval = _check_fill_value(fill_val, ndtype) 
```

i.e., it checked the wrong variable, `fill_val` (which was set several lines above and had already been checked).

I think what the test probably wanted to do is:

```
fill_value = np.ndarray(shape=(), dtype=object)
fill_value[()] = (-999, -12345678.9, "???")
```

@seberg - that would make sense, except that it is what I already turned the test above into... (if written a bit more clumsily).

Shall I just remove it?
Ah, didn't realize there were two tests here. Can't figure out what the other version would be supposed to mean either right now.
